did.head: Descriptive Summary

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: Hoover Institution on War, Revolution, and Peace

did.abstract: Speeches and writings, correspondence, notes, statistics, memoranda, reports, and printed matter, relating to international population changes, changes in family structure, and urbanization.
did.langmaterial: Languages represented in the collection: English

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. Access to audiovisual materials requires at least two weeks advance notice. Audiovisual materials include sound recordings, video recordings, and motion picture film. Hoover staff will determine whether use copies of the materials requested can be made available. Some materials may not be accessible even with advance notice. Please contact the Hoover Institution Archives Audiovisual Specialist for further information.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Kingsley Davis Papers, [Box no.], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Materials were acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 1983.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog Socrates at http://library.stanford.edu/webcat. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in Socrates is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The Kingsley Davis Papers, acquired in 1983, consist of correspondence, memoranda, notes, printed matter, reports, statistics, and speeches and writings, relating to international population changes, changes in family structure, and urbanization. Davis used some of this material as research materials for his numerous books on urbanization and population growth.

scopecontent.p: The diary of Davis' 1952 journey through Africa consists of 114 typewritten pages dating from October 2nd to December 5th 1952, and contains descriptions of the following countries: Democratic Republic of Congo, Republic of Congo, Burundi, Rwanda, Uganda, Angola, Cameroon, Gabon, Nigeria, Ghana, and Ivory Coast. Urban development within Africa is discussed extensively, and includes Davis's observations of the following cities: Leopoldville (now Kinshasa), Elizabethville (now Lubumbashi), Costermansville (now Bukavu), Usumbura (now Bujumbura), Astrida (now Butare), Kigali, Butembo, Brazzaville, Luanda, Douala, Libreville, Yaounde, Lagos, Ibadan, Kano, Kaduna, Accra, Kumasi, Tarkwa, Takoradi, and Abidjan. Other content of the diary examines traditional native cultures, colonial administration, regional economies, business enterprises, race relations, climate, and other topics.
